title: Stoichiometry — Limiting Reagent
question: For the reaction 2 H₂(g) + O₂(g) → 2 H₂O(l), you start with 4.00 mol H₂ and 1.50 mol O₂. Which is the limiting reagent?

choices.label: C
choices.text: Neither — both are in stoichiometric amounts

hint: Compare required O₂ for given H₂: need 1 mol O₂ per 2 mol H₂.
solution: For 4.00 mol H₂ the required O₂ = (4.00 mol H₂) × (1 mol O₂ / 2 mol H₂) = 2.00 mol O₂. Available O₂ = 1.50 mol < 2.00 mol required, so O₂ is limiting.

title: pH — Strong Acid Solution
question: What is the pH of a 0.0500 M HCl solution (assume complete dissociation)?
hint: pH = −log₁₀[H⁺].

title: Calorimetry — Heating Water
question: How much heat (q) is required to raise the temperature of 25.0 g of liquid water from 20.0 °C to 80.0 °C? (Use c = 4.184 J·g⁻¹·°C⁻¹.)
hint: q = m · c · ΔT. Convert J to kJ for answers.

title: Buffer — Henderson–Hasselbalch
question: Calculate the pH of a buffer made from 0.100 M acetic acid (HA) and 0.150 M sodium acetate (A⁻). (pKa = 4.76.)
hint: Use Henderson–Hasselbalch: pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]).

title: Ideal Gas — Molar Mass Determination
question: A 0.500 g sample of an unknown gaseous compound occupies 112.0 mL at 1.00 atm and 298 K. What is its molar mass? (R = 0.082057 L·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹)
hint: Find n from PV = nRT, then M = mass / n. Convert mL → L.

title: Kinetics — Second-Order Half-Life
question: For a second-order reaction with rate law rate = k[A]², the half-life is t₁/₂ = 1/(k[A]₀). If k = 0.250 M⁻¹·s⁻¹ and [A]₀ = 0.200 M, what is t₁/₂?
hint: Plug values into t₁/₂ = 1 / (k [A]₀).

title: Genetics — Monohybrid Cross
question: If an organism with genotype Aa is crossed with aa, what fraction of offspring are expected to be heterozygous (Aa)?
hint: List gametes from each parent: Aa → A or a; aa → a only.
solution: Parent genotypes: Aa × aa. Gametes: Aa → {A, a} each 1/2, aa → {a}. Offspring: 1/2 × a → Aa, 1/2 × a → aa → so 1/2 of offspring are Aa.

title: Electrochemistry — Nernst Equation
question: For the Cu²⁺/Cu half-reaction (Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu) with E° = +0.34 V, what is the electrode potential at 25.0 °C when [Cu²⁺] = 0.0100 M? (Use E = E° − (0.05916/2)·log₁₀(Q).)
hint: Q = 1 / [Cu²⁺] for the reduction as written (solid Cu activity = 1).

title: Enzyme Kinetics — Michaelis–Menten
question: An enzyme has Km = 5.0 μM. If [S] = 5.0 μM, what fraction of Vmax is the reaction velocity v (assuming Michaelis–Menten kinetics)?
hint: When [S] = Km, the Michaelis–Menten equation yields v = Vmax/2.
solution: By definition, when [S] = Km, v = (Vmax [S]) / (Km + [S]) = Vmax × Km / (Km + Km) = Vmax × 1/2 = 0.50 × Vmax.

title: Spectroscopy — ¹H NMR Chemical Shift
question: In ¹H NMR spectroscopy, which type of proton typically appears downfield near 9–10 ppm?
hint: Look for the proton on a carbonyl carbon in aldehydes.
solution: Aldehyde protons (–CHO) are deshielded by the adjacent carbonyl and typically appear around 9–10 ppm in ¹H NMR.

title: Osmolarity — Ionic Dissociation
question: What is the osmolarity (in Osm·L⁻¹) of a 0.150 M Na₂SO₄ solution assuming complete dissociation into ions?
hint: Na₂SO₄ dissociates into 3 ions (2 Na⁺ + SO₄²⁻) per formula unit; osmolarity = concentration × i.
solution: Van't Hoff factor i = 3. Osmolarity = 0.150 M × 3 = 0.450 Osm·L⁻¹.

title: Titration — Half-Equivalence Point
question: You titrate 0.100 M acetic acid with 0.100 M NaOH. At the half-equivalence point (half of the acid neutralized), what is the pH of the solution? (pKa acetic acid = 4.76)
hint: At half-equivalence [A⁻] = [HA]; Henderson–Hasselbalch simplifies to pH = pKa.
solution: At the half-equivalence point [A⁻] = [HA], so pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]) = pKa + log(1) = pKa = 4.76.

title: Ideal Gas Law — Moles
question: A 2.46 L container holds an ideal gas at 1.50 atm and 298 K. Using R = 0.082057 L·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹, how many moles of gas are present?
hint: Use PV = nRT → n = PV / (RT).
solution:
Compute n = PV / (RT).
Step 1 (numerator): P × V = 1.50 atm × 2.46 L = 3.6900 (atm·L).
Step 2 (denominator): R × T = 0.082057 L·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ × 298 K = 24.452986 (L·atm·mol⁻¹).
Step 3: n = 3.6900 / 24.452986 = 0.150895 ≈ 0.151 mol.

title: Colligative Properties — Freezing Point Depression
question: What is the freezing point of an aqueous solution that is 3.00 m (molal) in NaCl, assuming complete dissociation (i = 2)? (Kf for water = 1.86 °C·kg·mol⁻¹)
hint: ΔTf = i · Kf · m; freezing point = 0 °C − ΔTf.

title: Electrochemistry — Cell Potential
question: Given the standard reduction potentials: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu (E° = +0.34 V) and Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Zn (E° = −0.76 V), what is the standard cell potential (E°cell) for a Daniell cell where Zn(s) | Zn²⁺ || Cu²⁺ | Cu(s)?
hint: E°cell = E°(cathode) − E°(anode). Zn is oxidized (anode), Cu is reduced (cathode).
solution: Cathode: Cu²⁺/Cu E° = +0.34 V. Anode: Zn²⁺/Zn E° = −0.76 V. E°cell = E°cathode − E°anode = 0.34 − (−0.76) = 1.10 V.

title: Reaction Kinetics — First-Order Half-Life
question: A first-order reaction has a rate constant k = 0.023 s⁻¹. What is the half-life t₁/₂ of the reaction?
hint: For first order, t₁/₂ = ln(2) / k. Use ln(2) ≈ 0.693147.

title: Spectroscopy — IR Identification
question: Which IR absorption band region is most characteristic of a carbonyl (C=O) stretch in a typical ketone or aldehyde?
hint: Look for a strong sharp band for C=O.
solution: Carbonyl (C=O) stretches typically appear near 1700 cm⁻¹ (range ≈1680–1750 cm⁻¹ depending on conjugation and environment).

title: Enzyme Inhibition — Kinetic Effects
question: Which description correctly matches competitive and noncompetitive inhibition effects on Km and Vmax?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Competitive: Km increases, Vmax unchanged. Noncompetitive: Km unchanged, Vmax decreases.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Competitive: Km decreases, Vmax decreases. Noncompetitive: Km increases, Vmax increases.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Competitive: Km unchanged, Vmax decreases. Noncompetitive: Km increases, Vmax unchanged.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Competitive: Km and Vmax both decrease. Noncompetitive: Km and Vmax both increase.

hint: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate for active site; noncompetitive inhibitors reduce catalytic efficiency regardless of substrate concentration.
solution: Competitive inhibitors raise the apparent Km (lower affinity) because more substrate is needed to reach the same velocity; Vmax is unchanged (can be reached at high [S]). Noncompetitive inhibitors bind elsewhere and reduce the effective concentration of active enzyme, decreasing Vmax while Km is unchanged.

title: Molecular Biology — PCR Steps
question: Place the core steps of PCR in the correct order for one cycle.
hint: Think: separate strands, primers bind, polymerase extends.
solution: Correct order: Denaturation (high temp to separate strands) → Annealing (lower temp for primers to bind) → Extension (DNA polymerase synthesizes new strand).

title: Genetics — Dihybrid Cross Probability
question: For a cross AaBb × AaBb (independent assortment), what is the probability that an offspring will be homozygous recessive for both traits (aabb)?
hint: Treat the two loci independently: probability aabb = P(aa) × P(bb). For Aa × Aa, P(aa)=1/4.
solution: P(aa) = 1/4 (from Aa×Aa). P(bb) = 1/4. Multiply independent probabilities: (1/4) × (1/4) = 1/16 = 0.0625.

title: Membrane Potential — Nernst Calculation
question: Using the Nernst equation at 37 °C (use 61.5 mV · log₁₀), calculate the equilibrium potential for K⁺ when [K⁺]₍in₎ = 140 mM and [K⁺]₍out₎ = 4 mM. (Give the sign and approximate magnitude.)
hint: E = 61.5 mV × log₁₀([out]/[in]) for a monovalent cation at 37 °C.

title: Oxidative Phosphorylation — Uncoupler Effect
question: If a protonophoric uncoupler (e.g., DNP) is added to mitochondria, which of the following describes the expected effects on the proton gradient, ATP synthesis rate, and O₂ consumption?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Proton gradient dissipates; ATP synthesis decreases; O₂ consumption increases.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Proton gradient increases; ATP synthesis increases; O₂ consumption decreases.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Proton gradient unchanged; ATP synthesis increases; O₂ consumption unchanged.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Proton gradient dissipates; ATP synthesis increases; O₂ consumption decreases.

hint: Uncouplers carry protons across membrane bypassing ATP synthase.
solution: Uncouplers collapse (dissipate) the proton gradient by shuttling protons back into the matrix without driving ATP synthase. This lowers ATP synthesis rate. The electron transport chain works harder (faster) to try to restore the gradient, so O₂ consumption increases.
